questions.text: A 14 year old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below and a bluish swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding management of NSTEMI

choices.text: Aspirin loading dose should be commenced immediately
ACC/ AHA guidelines call for either a P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, prasugrel or ticagrelor) as a class I recommendation
Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitors are useful adjuncts
Fibrinolytic therapy is useful in acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation

questions.solution:
A distinction in acute coronary syndrome between patients with and without ST-segment elevation at presentation is essential to determine the need for reperfusion therapy.

Fibrinolytic therapy is harmful in acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation, unlike with ST-segment elevation, where acute reperfusion saves lives.

Antiplatelet and anticoagulation therapies and coronary intervention are mainstays of treatment.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Among the following, which is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of jejunoileal atresia, and among the options CECT abdomen is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in proximal bowel atresia such as duodenal atresia whereas abdominal distension with bilious vomiting is more with distal small bowel atresia such as jejuno-ileal atresia. Jejuno-ileal atresia is the most GI atresia.

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

  • Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance
  • Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance

A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. 

 

In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

An erect X-ray of the abdomen showing ileal atresia. The image shows a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of ileal atresia.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for Legionnaire’s disease?
questions.solution:
The antibiotics of choice in a patient with Legionnaire's disease are macrolides.

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditions, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest X-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. This leads to this infection being included in a differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia.

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever may also occur which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria very poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

 Macrolides and quinolones are the drugs of choice for this condition.

 

As L.pneumophila are intracellular pathogens, antibiotics that reach high intracellular concentration must be used. Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice and are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, agents like doxycycline may also be used. B-lactams, monobactams and aminoglycosides are not considered to be effective. Total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients. 

Gram staining of pleural fluid showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli causative organism of Legionnaire’s disease, Legionella pneumophila.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of 500 patients having carcinoma lung and another group of 300 was chosen from the general population. Both these groups were assessed on their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution: This is a case–control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people constitute the controls, and the study is done from effect to cause as the disease has already occurred.

questions.text: What is the pattern of inheritance in neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance in neural tube defects(NTDs) is multifactorial inheritance.

Multifactorial inheritance refers to traits that are caused by a combination of inherited, environmental, and stochastic factors. NTDs and a number of other congenital malformations, such as cleft lip and palate, can recur in families, but inheritance for the majority of affected individuals does not occur in a straightforward, mendelian inheritance pattern. In this situation, multiple genes and environmental factors together likely contribute to the pathogenesis.

These include the following: 

Children (congenital malformation)

   Adults

Pyloric stenosis

Neural tube defects

Congenital heart defects

Congenital dislocation of hip

Cleft lip and cleft palate

 Diabetes Mellitus

 Hypertension

 Coronary heart disease

 Gout

 Schizophrenia

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given radiograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The given radiograph of a newborn shows imperforate anus/anal atresia. 

Anorectal atresia, also known as imperforate anus, refers to a spectrum of abnormalities of the rectum and anus. There are many possible abnormalities as follows:

  1. The absence of an anal opening.
  2. The anal opening is in the wrong place.
  3. A connection, or fistula, joining the intestine and urinary system.
  4. A connection joining the intestine and vagina.
  5. In females, the intestine can join with the urinary system and vagina in a single opening, known as a cloaca.

Incidence is one in every 5,000 live births.

The newborn presents with an inability to pass meconium, abdominal distension, anal dimple, and sometimes passing meconium per urethra. It is divided into low intermediate and high lyings according to the Wingspread classification. Diagnosis is done using Wangenstein invertogram . Treatment is surgical.

questions.text: A known hypertensive patient is brought to the ER with palpitations and breathlessness. On examination, his BP was 220/140 with signs of encephalopathy. Which of the following is used as a 1st line drug to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a diagnosis of hypertensive emergency. The first-line drug in this scenario is IV nicardipine.

Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD).

Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents.

In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction.

The table below shows the treatment of various hypertensive emergencies.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation to establish a diagnosis of GERD?
questions.solution:
24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring is the ‘gold standard’ to establish a diagnosis of GERD.

  • Transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxations are the most important manometric findings in GERD.

24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring in GERD:

  • In the proximal esophagus (15 cm above the LES), acid exposure normally occurs less than 1% of the time.
  • In the distal esophagus (5 cm above the LES), it normally occurs less than 4% of the time.

De Meester score

  • An overall score is obtained with the use of a formula that assigns a weight to each item according to its capacity to cause esophageal injury.
  • A value greater than 14.7 indicates reflux.

questions.text: Interpret the finding of the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a regular rhythm, narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent P waves is suggestive of supraventricular tachycardia. 

Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles

  • Tachycardias originating from the atrium:
    • Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node
    • Focal atrial tachycardia
    • Multifocal atrial tachycardia
    • Atrial flutter 
    • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tachycardias originating from the AV node:
    • Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node
    • AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT)
  • Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia(AVRT).

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is given below.

ECG in Atrial fibrillation also shows absent p waves, narrow QRS complex, and irregularly irregular RR interval with a heart rate ranging between 110-160 beats/minute

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. An X-ray of her skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
  • Urinalysis: positive for Bence-Jones proteins
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia, osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins, and Bence Jones proteinuria make multiple myeloma the most likely diagnosis.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia elevated ESR, Hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20% plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically:(CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT.
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is at least 5 mm or greater in size.

Note:

  • The presence of at least one of these markers is considered sufficient for a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms or CRAB features.
  • Each of these markers has been shown to be associated with an approximately 80% or higher risk of developing myeloma-related organ damage within two years.

 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 30 g/L and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of developing into invasive ductal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Squamous metaplasia has the least risk of developing into invasive ductal carcinoma. 

Related Pearl: Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue

No increased risk

  • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
  • Apocrine metaplasia
  • Cysts, macro and/or micro
  • Duct ectasia
  • Fibroadenoma
  • Fibrosis
  • Hyperplasia
  • Mastitis (inflammation)
  • Periductal mastitis
  • Squamous metaplasia

Slightly increased risk (1.5–2 times)

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid, or papillary
  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core

Moderately increased risk (5 times)

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)

Insufficient data to assign a risk

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
  • Radial scar lesion

questions.text: Which of the following represents type III choledochal cyst from the given image?
questions.solution:
The figure marked C in the given image represents choledochal cyst type III, a cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Choledochal cysts:

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in females.

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues has been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Caroli's disease:

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition of multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani's classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on the HIDA scan and the central dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice.

Treatment options:

  • Type I—excision of the cyst with its mucosa and reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
  • In type II—excision of the diverticulum and suturing of the CBD wall can be done
  • Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • Type IV, if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of the cyst wall over the portal vein is left behind. But mucosa of the part should be removed. This is named Lily’s operation.
  • Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of the biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required which can be removed by hepatectomy.
  • Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice in type IV and type V.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: The diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome include all of the following except ______

choices.text: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast

questions.solution: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48-hour fast is not a diagnostic criteria for IBS.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg, pulses were feeble. JVP was found to be elevated with an absent 'y descent', and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with Beck's triad including hypotension, muffled heart sounds and elevated JVP suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. 

Symptoms of cardiac tamponade include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue. Examination findings are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration
  • Beck's triad: Distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds and hypotension.

An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow. ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction.

Management of cardiac tamponade:

  • Emergency management - ultrasound-guided needle pericardiocentesis via subxiphoid route 
  • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A labourer's younger child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age Seen in older children (6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
NO edema Edema is prominent
Voracious appetite, no apathy Apathy and loss of appetite
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen
No Fatty liver, no subcutaneous fat Fatty liver, Subcutaneous fat preserved

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child is brought to the OPD with cramping abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rashes on the back of her legs, buttocks and the extensor surface of her forearms. Laboratory analysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this child with rash, abdominal pain and nephritis is Henoch-Schönlein purpura.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterized by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis

Children usually present with the following features:

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks.
  • Arthralgia and arthritis- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, and intussusception.
  • About 30% of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, presenting as microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal. 

Most clinical features of IgA vasculitis are self-limiting and resolve in a few days. Supportive management with the maintenance of hydration and pain relief is done. Patients developing nephritis due to IgA vasculitis may need aggressive management with immunosuppressants.

The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP.

questions.text: Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. 

Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness

Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula. It is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. 

The following images show the cannula placed in the cervix for the procedure:

Other cannula used for the same purpose is the Rubin’s cannula which is shown below:

The image given below is the myomectomy screw.

questions.text: You notice this  specialized vaporizer being used in the OT. Which of the following gases would you expect it to contain?
questions.solution:
The image shows a specialized vapouriser Tec 6. Because of high vapor pressure (669 mmHg at 20°C) and low boiling point (22.8°C ~ room temperature), Desflurane requires this specialized vaporizer for its delivery.

Anesthetic gas with the highest vapor pressure is Desflurane. 

Other salient features of Desflurane:

  • High saturated vapor pressure which is 3-4 times the other agents
  • Low boiling point 
  • Low blood-gas solubility (0.42) resulting in rapid uptake and recovery
  • High MAC value of 6, indicating low potency
  • Requires specialized vapouriser such as Tec 6
  • Color coding of Desflurane - Blue
  • Undergoes minimal metabolism
  • Degraded into CO by the desiccated CO2 absorbent

questions.text: A young adult with gastric outlet obstruction presents with vomiting. Which of the following fluids is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Normal saline is preferred in a patient with gastric outlet obstruction to rectify the electrolyte imbalance. 

The recurrent vomiting secondary to the gastric outlet obstruction leads to dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis. This abnormality has to be corrected and adequate rehydration ensured before the surgery is undertaken. The patient should be rehydrated with intravenous isotonic saline with potassium supplementation. Replacing the sodium chloride and water allows the kidney to correct the acid–base abnormality. (Normal saline has more chloride than Ringer lactate)

Surgery can be done once the electrolyte imbalance is corrected - Routine preoperative evaluation is conducted, oral feeding is discontinued and the stomach is emptied with a nasogastric tube. Intravenous fluids are given to replace the ongoing gastric losses.

Fluid Resuscitation

  • Fluid resuscitation - 0.9% saline with KCl in 5% glucose provides maintenance and corrects deficits in most babies. As the chloride deficit is replaced, the kidneys correct the pH. 
  • The urine output should be monitored and the electrolyte levels must be checked every 6 hours.
  • To ensure that rehydration has occurred, the urine output should be >2 cc/Kg/hr.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. What is the probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the above-mentioned clinical presentation is Mallory Weiss tear as the patient's vitals are stable.

Mallory Weiss Syndrome:

  • It is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of longitudinal superficial mucosal lacerations (Mallory-Weiss tears).
  • They occur primarily in the lower esophagus close to the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It mainly occurs in patients with repetitive forceful retching and vomiting and is associated with heavy alcohol intake.
  • The concurrent presence of portal hypertension with esophageal varices and hiatal hernia in patients with Mallory Weiss syndrome is not uncommon.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • It is a transmural perforation of the esophagus (while the Mallory Weiss tear is a mucosal tear).
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Mackler's Triad:
      • Vomiting
      • lower thoracic pain
      • subcutaneous emphysema
    • Other classical findings include deranged vitals tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension.
    • Diaphoresis and abdominal rigidity can also be present

questions.text: Absent P waves is a feature of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Absent 'p' waves in an ECG is a feature of atrial fibrillation. The other features observed are narrow QRS complexes, irregular RR intervals, and irregularly irregular rhythm. 

Atrial fibrillation is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. The incidence of AF increases with age and is usually associated with an acute precipitating factor such as acute alcohol intoxication.

The image of the ECG given below shows absent 'p' waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation.

The image given above represents multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly affected organ in sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the lungs.

It is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, liver, and eyes.

The characteristic features of lung involvement in sarcoidosis include bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, predilection for the upper lobes, and interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complaints of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. Identify the given clinical scenario.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of a tubal block. 

The presenting complaints of tubal block are: 

  • Dysmenorrhea 
  • Pelvic pain 
  • Inability to conceive 
  • Repeated episodes of PID 
  • History of ectopic pregnancy 

Tubal block can be due to:

  • Strictures - fibrotic block
  • Inspissated amorphous material
  • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radio-opaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle). 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods & obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound image given below showing an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery(a string of pearls) is indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts, an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other Options:

Option B: Molar Pregnancy will produce a characteristic Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option C: Enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option D: The image below depicts multiple theca lutein cysts.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 30 year old pregnant female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The woman here is presenting with chloasma or mask of pregnancy. The same facial melanosis in non-pregnant women is called melasma. Only the terms used differ.

  • Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, and chin.
  • It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years.
  • Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and melasma is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.

Wood's Lamp examination is useful to differentiate the level of pigmentation and therefore the response to treatment.

Chloasma self resolves after pregnancy but melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like

  • Kligman's triple combination - Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream [First line]
  • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
  • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

questions.text: The specimen in the below image was obtained from a woman's stomach. Which specialist is recommended alongside a surgeon in this case?
questions.solution:
The given image of a trichobezoar suggests a diagnosis of trichophagia, which mandates a detailed evaluation by a psychiatrist. 

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. Complications include trichobezoars, malnutrition, and intestinal obstruction.

Trichotillomania is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by repetitive hair pulling, leading to variable hair loss. There is increased tension prior to the hair pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair pulling. It is seen more common in females.

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution or ressortment of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with a painless swelling in the neck. Histopathological examination reveals the following findings as shown in image below and she is diagnosed with follicular cell carcinoma, with involvement of level VI neck lymph nodes. What would be the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation
Total thyroidectomy with lateral neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of follicular thyroid carcinoma wih level VI neck lymph node involvement, total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection is the appropriate management.

The histopathological image with sheets of cells forming follicles with capsular invasion is shown below.

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is the most common thyroid cancer in iodine-deficient areas. Peak incidence occurs between 40-60 years of age. It is more common in females. It usually presents as a solitary nodule, which is well-encapsulated.

It has a hematogenous spread. The most common site of distant metastasis is Bones > Lung. Osteolytic, pulsatile bone metastasis is seen due to hypervascularity.  

Diagnosis of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) requires demonstration of capsular or vascular or lymphatic invasion which cannot be determined with Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB). So, follicular thyroid adenoma cannot be differentiated from Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) via FNAB.

Total thyroidectomy is recommended in case of high-risk features such as,

  • Older patients (>40 years of age) with follicular lesions >4 cm.
  • Capsular, Vascular, or lymphatic invasion.
  • Family history, metastases, atypia.
  • History of radiation exposure

Management of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is as follows:

Total Thyroidectomy :

  • 2-4 cm Tumor size with high-risk features or Capsular, Lymphatic, Vascular invasion.

  •  >4cm Tumor size.

Hemithyroidectomy:

  • ≤ 2 cm Tumor size.
  • 2-4 cm Tumor size without high-risk features.
     

Lymph node involvement is not common. Hence, prophylactic neck dissection is not needed.

If central lymph nodes are involved - Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection.

If other lymph nodes are involved - Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection (option c ).

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

Low-risk DTC
(Fulfilling all 5 of the following conditions)

  1. < 40 years (better prognosis)
  2. Unifocal lesion
  3. Size < 2 cm
  4. No lymphovascular invasion
  5. No capsular invasion
 Hemithyroidectomy

High- risk DTC without LN involvement
(not fulfilling all of the above 5 conditions)

 Total thyroidectomy

High-risk DTC + level VI LN involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection

High-risk DTC + other LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling
  • Sensation of poor bladder emptying
  • Episodes of near retention

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.text: 10 months old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the right testis was found in the right inguinal canal, while the left testis was found in the perineum.  Comment on the diagnosis of this baby.

choices.text: Right side undescended testis and left sided ectopic testis
Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.solution:
Since the right testis is found in the inguinal canal which is along the normal path of descent it is called an undescended testis, while the left testis lies in the perineum which is an ectopic site of descent and is called an ectopic testis.

  • The ectopic testis is one that has ended up away from the normal path of descent. The commonest site is the superficial inguinal pouch.
  • Cryptorchidism or undescended testis is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

The image below shows the possible ectopic sites of the testes:

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction.

Therefore any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal (normal rugosity is seen).

Retractile testes require no treatment 

Note: Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them describe a condition, wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

Chair Test:  Here, The young patient is asked to sit on a chair hugging his knees to his chest. This maneuver helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum. By this test retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

questions.text: Identify the hormone present in the contraceptive shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The contraceptive device shown in the above image is ‘Today’. It contains nonoxynol 9. 

Today:

It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane disposal sponge

2 inches in diameter, 1.25 inches thick and contains 1 g of nonoxynol-9.

It is provided with a loop for its easy removal.

It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix.

It can remain effective for 24 h. It is used only once. It acts as a mechanical barrier and prevents entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs semen and contains a spermicidal agent.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year   Example
First tier  < 2 % IUD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal (oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings)
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of tingling sensation in hands and feet, generalised weakness, easy fatiguability, pallor, and ataxia. Deficiency of which vitamin causes these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. 

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in: 

  • Generalized weakness
  • Easy fatiguability
  • Pallor
  • Paresthesia in hands and feet (tingling sensation)
  • Loss of sense of position and sensation of vibration
  • Progressive spastic and ataxic weakness
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Patients present with generalized weakness, easy fatiguability, and pallor due to megaloblastic anemia which is a consequence of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, corneal vascularization

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Relatively unknown

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. He also complains of excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Placing an ice pack over his eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or during late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in a post-menopausal woman on hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
questions.solution:
Adding progesterone to estrogen in HRT can reduce the risk of potential endometrial cancer.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of oestrogen therapy. For women without a uterus, just estrogen therapy is sufficient. 

Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms,genitourinary syndrome of menopause like vaginal and vulvar atrophy and for the prevention of osteoporosis.

The daily estrogen content in most oral contraceptive pills is 35µg or less and levonorgestrel is 100-150 mg. But the HRT commonly used have a different concentration of estrogen and progesterone. Hence the regular combined oral contraceptive pills are not used.

Clonidine reduces hot flashes during menopause but does not have any action on endometrium. Vitamin E has no role in endometriual proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is breast milk deficient in?
questions.solution:
Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K.

Therefore infants have to be supplemented with vitamin K to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains many antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the baby's optimum growth as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

Breastmilk is also deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented.

Human milk is a rich source of vitamin C and contains around 5-15mg/100cal. Vitamin C is found in higher levels in breast milk than in cow milk.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a 2-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of seizures in the said age group is febrile seizures. 

Febrile seizures are defined as seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 to 60 months
  • Associated with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Do not occur as a result of central nervous system infections or any metabolic imbalance.
  • Occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures.

Depending on the duration and recurrence of the febrile seizure, they are classified as follows:

  • Simple febrile seizure: Generalised, usually tonic-clonic seizure, lasting for ≤15 minutes, and not recurrent within 24 hours.
  • Complex febrile seizures: Focal seizure, which is prolonged for >15 minutes and/or recurs in 24 hours.
  • Febrile status epilepticus: Febrile seizure lasting for >30 minutes.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be ______
questions.solution:
The dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) in this case is 800 mcg.
Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal Misoprostol administration.


Medical management protocol for induced abortion for < 12 weeks of gestation (As per WHO 2018 guideline):

  • Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9 weeks).

First trimester:

Mifepristone/misoprostol combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol

Misoprostol-only regimen (alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Methotrexate/misoprostol:

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given

 
Second trimester:

Mifepristone/misoprostol combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol alone (alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone: 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated oxytocin:

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline
 

Note: This recommendation has been updated from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance. This updated recommendation applies to pregnancies up to 12 weeks of gestation, whereas, in the prior guidance, different regimens were recommended for pregnancies up to 7 weeks, 9 weeks, and 12 weeks.

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol

INDICATIONS PRIMARY DOSE OF MISOPROSTOL REMARKS

MEDICAL TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY

 

Combined Regimen(recommended):
Upto 12 weeks of gestation-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually.

Beyond 12 weeks of gestation-400mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually every 3 hours


Misoprostol only regimen:
Upto 12 weeks-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually

Beyond 12 weeks-400mcg vaginally, bucally or sublingually every 3 hours

Ideally used 1-2 days after 200mg of Mifepristone in the combined regimen.

SURGICAL ABORTION

12-14weeks- both medical and surgical methods can be done

>14weeks-surgical method 

 Cervical preparation: 400mcg vaginally/ sublingually

Another method: Oral Mifepristone 200mg 24-48 hours before the procedure

 
PPH Prophylaxis 800mcg sublingual single dose OR 600mcg orally single dose for PPH secondary prevention (approx >350ml blood loss)  Where oxytocin is not available or storage conditions are inadequate
PPH treatment 800 mcg sublingually single dose

NOTE:

  1. The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.
  2. The dose suggested in the medical termination of pregnancy also includes incomplete abortion and missed abortion.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: What is the ideal time and method of removing hair before surgery to avoid surgical site infection?

choices.text: On the OT table with electric hair clippers
With a razor 24 hours before surgery
With a hair removal cream on the previous day
On the OT table with a razor

questions.solution:
To avoid surgical site infection, hair should be removed on the OT table with electric hair clippers. 

Measures to decrease the incidence of surgical site infections (SSIs)

Patient preparation:

1) Smoking cessation four to six weeks prior to elective surgery is recommended to decrease the incidence of pulmonary complications. 

2) Bowel preparation prior to abdominal surgeries is expected to decrease the incidence of SSIs.

Infection control:

1) Timely administration of preoperative antimicrobial prophylaxis.

2) All surgical team members must practice appropriate surgical hand hygiene measures.

3) Surgeons and other team members within the premises of the operation theater should routinely wear barrier clothing such as scrubs, caps, and gowns.

4) Preoperatively, the patient must be advised to use topical mupirocin and bathe with chlorhexidine to aid in Staphylococcus aureus decolonization.

5) Shaving hair with razors at the operative site is not advised. If hair removal is absolutely necessary, it may be performed with hair clippers.

Miscellaneous perioperative measures:

1) Maintain normothermic OT

2) Ensure laminar airflow

3) Minimise red cell transfusions

4) Ensure adequate glycemic control.

questions.text: A chronic smoker wants to quit smoking. Which of the following drugs would help him with his goal?
questions.solution:
Bupropion and Varenicline are used for smoking cessation.

Bupropion:

  • It enhances both noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission by inhibiting reuptake.
  • Used for aiding smoking cessation and for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs.
  • Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. 
  • It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Varenicline:

  • Nicotinic ACh receptor partial agonist.
  • Used for smoking cessation.
  • Side effects: Sleep disturbance, may depress mood and increase suicidal tendencies.

Mirtazapine:

  • Serotonin receptor antagonist.
  • Used for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs and for insomnia in depressive patients.
  • Side effect: Sedation.

questions.text: A tall male presents with absent pubic and axillary hair, infantile genitalia, high LH and FSH levels with XXY karyotype. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of Klinefelter's syndrome (KS).

The classic form of KS (47,XXY) occurs after meiotic nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes during gametogenesis. Mosaic forms of KS (46,XY/47,XXY) are thought to result from chromosomal mitotic nondisjunction within the zygote and occur in at least 10% of individuals with this condition. Other chromosomal variants of KS (e.g., 48,XXYY, 48,XXXY) have been reported but are less common.

KS is characterized by small testes, infertility, gynecomastia, tall stature/increased leg length, and hypogonadism. Testes are small and firm (median length 2.5 cm/4 mL, almost always <3.5 cm/ 12 mL) and typically seem inappropriately small for the degree of androgenization.

Plasma concentrations of FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) are increased in most adults with 47,XXY, and plasma testosterone is decreased (50–75%), reflecting primary gonadal failure. Patients with mosaic forms of KS have less severe clinical features, have larger testes, and sometimes achieve spontaneous fertility.

Treatment:

  • Growth, endocrine function, and bone mineralization should be monitored, especially from adolescence.
  • Educational and psychological support is important for many individuals with KS.
  • Androgen supplementation improves virilization, libido, energy, hypofibrinolysis, and bone mineralization in men with low testosterone levels but may occasionally worsen gynecomastia.
  • Gynecomastia can be treated by surgical reduction if it causes concern.
  • Fertility has been achieved by using in vitro fertilization in men with oligospermia or with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) after retrieval of spermatozoa by testicular sperm extraction techniques.
  • Long-term monitoring of men with KS is important given the increased risk of breast cancer, cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, and autoimmune disorders.
