questions.text: When does secondary post-partum haemorrhage develop?

choices.text: Shortly after the delivery of placenta

questions.solution:
Secondary postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) occurs between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery. 

Types of PPH:

  • Primary: haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth
    • Most common cause: atonic PPH
  • Secondary: haemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum
    • Most common cause: retained placenta

Causes of PPH (mnemonic: 4’T’):

  • T - Tone: Atonic PPH
  • T - Trauma: Traumatic PPH
  • T - Thrombin: Coagulopathy (DIC and hypofibrinogenemia)
  • T - Tissue: retained products of conception.

questions.text: Ritodrine, which prevents premature labour, causes all of the following maternal complications, except:
questions.solution:
Ritodrine when administered predisposes to fetal hypoglycaemia and maternal hyperglycaemia.

Preterm labour and delivery (labour starts before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period) can be delayed by drugs such as ritodrine, in order to improve the perinatal outcome. A short-term delay of 48 hours allows the use of corticosteroids that can reduce perinatal mortality and serious morbidity significantly.

Complications of ritodrine are as follows :

  1. Maternal:
  • Headache
  • Palpitation
  • Tachycardia
  • Pulmonary oedema
  • Hypotension
  • Cardiac failure
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Hyperinsulinemia
  • Lactic acidemia
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Potential death

2. Fetal:

  • Hypoglycaemia
  • Intraventricular haemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is not used for brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for systemic radiotherapy.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which a radioactive source is placed directly into or near the target tissue to deliver localized radiation treatment. It is commonly used for treating various types of cancer.

Other options:

A) Iodine-125: This radioactive isotope is commonly used in brachytherapy for treating prostate cancer. It emits low-energy gamma rays that can effectively target and treat the cancerous tissue.

C) Cobalt-60: This isotope is not typically used in brachytherapy but rather in external beam radiation therapy. Cobalt-60 emits high-energy gamma rays and is commonly used in radiation therapy machines called cobalt units or teletherapy units. These units deliver radiation from outside the body, targeting the tumor.

D) Iridium-192: This is a commonly used radioactive isotope in brachytherapy. It emits high-energy gamma rays and is used for treating various types of cancer, such as cervical, prostate, and breast cancer. Iridium-192 is often used in temporary brachytherapy, where the radioactive source is temporarily placed in the body and then removed after a specific period of treatment.

In summary, while Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are commonly used in brachytherapy, Cobalt-60 is primarily used in external beam radiation therapy. Iodine-131 is not typically used in brachytherapy but has other medical applications, such as thyroid cancer treatment and diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A 34 year old male presents with a history of progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past 6 months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve on exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray image are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis The clinical presentation of a young male with progressive lower backache, morning stiffness, a symptomatic improvement on exercise, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are features supportive of the diagnosis. It is an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain. Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis. Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • Periarticular sclerosis (option B) in later stages 
  • Squaring of vertebrae due to flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • Bamboo spine appearance (option C) due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • Wedging of the vertebra (option D) leading to hyperkyphosis

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious in onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at the age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for > three months 

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of multiple neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents plaque psoriasis. The characteristic histopathological finding in psoriasis consists of multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum i.e Munro’s microabscesses and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis i.e spongiform pustules of Kogoj.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type. The nails are frequently involved and punctate pitting is the most common finding seen. Psoriasis is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon. It describes the appearance of new lesions along the site of trauma (linear lesions)

  • The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management. Phototherapy and oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine can also be used.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids 

 

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1mg/dl, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

Related Pearl: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

Disorder Inheritance Defects in bilirubin metabolism Clinical course

Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I

AR

occasional kernicterus

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

Fallopian tube in genital tuberculosis:

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. 

The ampulla is most commonly affected while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Hysterosalpingography may reveal the following: 

  • Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)
  • Beading and variation due to filling defects
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and presence of ulcers.

questions.text: Which phase of the menstrual cycle features vacuolation as a histological feature?
questions.solution:
Subnuclear vacuolation is a histological feature of the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. 

The histological features as per the respective phases are:

Proliferative/oestrogenic phase:

  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium
  • The endometrium is thick, stoma compact, and short straight glands are present.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled

Secretory phase :

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
  • Corkscrew-shaped glands

Menstrual Phase:

  • Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots. 

The image below shows secretory endometrium:

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presented with worsening hip and back pain. He also reports weight loss and loss of appetite. His PSA levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Blastic lesions on X-Ray along with elevated PSA levels, loss of weight, and loss of appetite are suggestive of prostatic carcinoma with metastasis to bones.

Carcinoma of the prostate:

It is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. They usually arise in the peripheral zone of the gland.

Prostate carcinoma is a type of adenocarcinoma. Therefore, histopathology shows the malignant cells arranged in the form of glands. In contrast to benign glands, malignant glands have tightly packed cells and characteristically lack branching and papillary infoldings. The outer basal cell layer typical of benign glands is absent. The cells may show increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, nuclear atypia, etc. α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) is positive and is upregulated in prostate cancer.

Local extension most commonly involves the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Advanced disease may produce ureteral obstruction. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the obturator nodes and the para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in the decreasing order of frequency. 

Management of Prostatic Carcinoma 
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

 

Below image shows histopathology of Prostate carcinoma:

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome(TLS). TLS is associated with hyperuricemia and rasburicase helps in decreasing the levels of uric acid in the blood.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

However, rituximab, gemtuzumab, and alemtuzumab are monoclonal antibodies that cause a rapid fall in circulating tumor cells upon infusion and may lead to TLS.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the given image showing abnormal dilation and enlargement of the scrotal venous pampiniform plexus,  like bag of worms is suggestive of a varicocele.

Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. Left-sided varicocele is more common. Most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the testicular vein by a renal tumour or nephrectomy is seen in some cases.

The pathogenesis behind varicocele is due to increased blood flow to the testis leading to higher intratesticular temperatures, which inhibits spermatogenesis and results in low sperm count, motility and morphology. Most varicoceles are asymptomatic. Those symptomatic tend to present in adolescence or early adulthood, with a dragging discomfort that is worse on standing at the end of the day. There may be a cough impulse. Additionally, patients may have infertility.

Grades of varicocele
Grade 1 Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 2 Varicocele palpable without Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 3 Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment. Treatment of symptomatic and young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:

  • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method )
  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) 
  • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route

In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate. 

Other options : 

Option a: Hydrocele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. In the case of a primary hydrocoele, as the fluid is collected within a closed sac, a cough impulse is unlikely to be seen. Important positive clinical findings in a hydrocoele are that they are irreducible,  the testes cannot be palpated separately, ability to get above the swelling, and transillumination of the swelling.

Option c : Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous.

Option d : Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract.

questions.text: All are true about Gullian-Barre syndrome except _________
questions.solution: Guillian–Barre syndrome is characterized by ascending symmetrical areflexic motor paralysis.

questions.text: A patient presents with backache, night sweats, an evening increase in temperature, and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in CRP and ESR levels. An MRI is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given spine MRI shows a patient with Pott's spine. The image depicts sagittal T1W (A) and T2W (B) images in a patient with spinal tuberculosis showing a well-defined, round lesion (arrow) with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity.

  • Pott's disease, also known as tuberculous spondylitis, refers to the vertebral body and intervertebral disc involvement in tuberculosis (TB).
  • The spine is the most frequent location of musculoskeletal TB, and commonly related symptoms are back pain and lower limb weakness/paraplegia.
  • The spine is involved due to hematogenous spread via the venous plexus of Batson.
  • There is usually a slow collapse of one or usually more vertebral bodies, which spreads underneath the longitudinal ligaments.
  • This results in an acute kyphotic or "gibbus" deformity.
  • This angulation, coupled with epidural granulation tissue and bony fragments, can lead to cord compression.

Radiographic Features:

Features include irregularity of both the endplate and anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, with bone marrow edema and enhancement seen on MRI:

  • T1: hypointense marrow in adjacent vertebrae
  • T2: hyperintense marrow, disc, soft tissue infection
  • T1 C+ (Gd): marrow, subligamentous, discal, dural enhancement

The paraspinal collections are typically well-circumscribed, with fluid centres and well-defined enhancing margins.

Other options: 

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis: shows Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

Option B: Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. Radiography shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance.

Option C: Pyogenic spondylitis denotes infections impacting different components of the spine, including the vertebrae, intervertebral discs, paraspinal soft tissue, or epidural space. This umbrella term covers conditions such as vertebral osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis, and epidural abscess.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the history of no previous illness is most likely of primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon:

  • Episodic digital ischemia due to the vasospasm of digital arteries.
  • Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger it.
  • The blanching/ischemic phase of the phenomenon with pallor/cyanosis is often accompanied by numbness and paraesthesia.
  • Capillaries and venules dilate and cyanosis results from the deoxygenated blood that is present in these vessels.
  • Color changes are usually well-demarcated and are confined to the fingers or toes.
  • In the rewarming phase, digital vasospasm resolves and blood flows into the dilated arterioles and capillaries increase dramatically causing reactive hyperemia which imparts bright red color to the digits.
  • Some may experience only pallor cyanosis while others experience both pallor and cyanosis.

Types of Raynaud's:
     1.Primary/idiopathic 

     2. Secondary associated with other diseases like: 

  • Collagen vascular diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • Arterial occlusive diseases: atherosclerosis of the extremities, thromboangiitis
    obliterans, acute arterial occlusion
  • Neurologic disorders: intervertebral disk disease, syringomyelia
  • Blood dyscrasias: cold agglutinins, cryoglobulinemia, cryofibrinogenemia,
  • Trauma: vibration injury, electric shock, cold injury, typing, piano playing
  • Drugs and toxins: ergot derivatives, methysergide, β-adrenergic receptor
    blockers

Management:

  • Reassurance, warm clothing, and avoiding cold exposures.
    exposure.
  • Reduce or abstain from smoking and reduce stress levels.
  • Drug treatments such as CCB's(nifedipine, amlodipine), alpha 1 blockers ( prazosin) are used only for advanced cases.
  • In secondary Raynauds's Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors like sildenafil, tadalafil may improve symptoms.

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, body temperature of less than 37 degrees, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
This child with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths/min has tachypnea/fast breathing without any danger signs has pneumonia according to IMNCI guidelines. The next best step of management is to administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home.

The treatment for pneumonia for a child between 2 months and 5 years of age is oral amoxicillin and home care advice.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 

 Danger signs:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

Tachypnea or Fast breathing is defined based on the age and respiratory rate:

Age of child Rate
<2 months 60 breaths/min
2-12 months 50 breaths/min
1-5 years 40 breaths/min

questions.text: A young male patient, who has a family history of bipolar disorder on his paternal side, has come to your OPD with 3 episodes of mania. Which of the following mood stabilizers can be given to him as the most effective treatment?
questions.solution:
Lithium is the drug of choice for maintenance therapy or prophylaxis of bipolar disorder. It is also the most effective long-term treatment for bipolar disorder. 

Related Pearl: Treatment of acute manic episode

There is no single drug of choice for the treatment of acute mania. 

If the patient is on anti-depressants: Stop antidepressants. 

If the patient is already on anti-manic medication: 

  • If already on lithium or valproate: increase the dose of lithium or valproate and consider adding an antipsychotic. 
  • Consider adding short-term benzodiazepines for all patients. 

If the patient is not on anti-manic medication:

  • Consider an antipsychotic if symptoms are severe and behavior is disturbed (or)
  • Consider valproate, but avoid in women of reproductive age (or)
  • Consider lithium if future adherence is likely 
  • Consider adding short-term benzodiazepines for all patients.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The patient is in respiratory distress and has visibly dilated neck veins. A large amount of air was noted on the left side in the X-ray as shown below. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space

questions.solution:
The given X-ray features and clinical scenario point towards the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. The next best step in the management is wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space.

The chest X-ray shows a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound – extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury 
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

Other options:

  • Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade which is characterized by the presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad). The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade.
  • Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy) in cases of spontaneous pneumothorax failing to settle despite chest drainage. Pleural adhesion is achieved by chemical pleurodesis where talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text: What does the following X-ray depict?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray depicts left-sided pleural effusion. 

The CXR shows:

  • Obliteration of costophrenic angle: due to accumulation of fluid on the affected side 
  • Air-fluid interface

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

  • Presence of free pleural fluid 
  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Ellis-S curve – This is a radiological illusion and occurs as a medial radiological density due to the presence of partially aerated lung between the anterior and posterior fluid layers, whereas laterally the density is higher due to the presence of fluid only. The actual fluid level is horizontal.

The image below depicts pleural effusion in chest X-ray PA view.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumour of the ovary in the reproductive age group?
questions.solution:
A benign teratoma or dermoid cyst is the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group. It is also the:

  • Most common benign tumor of ovary diagnosed in pregnancy
  • Most common germ cell tumor (overall)
  • Most typical tumor to undergo torsion.
  • Bilateral in 10-15% cases.

It consists of a Rokitansky’s protuberance, which is a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands along with teeth & bones can be seen. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological study – known as Struma Ovarii. The most common tissue elements found are ectodermal derivatives.

questions.text: A 21 year old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her friend revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm and RR was 36 /min. Which of the following is not a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) following septic abortion. Escherichia coli can be detected in septic abortion but it is not a causative agent for TSS.

Organisms causing toxic shock syndrome in septic abortion are:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Clostridium sordellii

Clinical features of septic abortion include:

  • Fever with chills and rigors
  • Abdominal or chest pain
  • Diarrhoea and vomiting
  • Renal angle tenderness
  • Offensive purulent vaginal discharge.

Clinical grading of septic abortion:

  • Grade I - infection localized in the uterus
  • Grade II - infection spreads to parametrium, tubes, ovaries, or pelvic peritoneum
  • Grade III - generalized peritonitis, endotoxic shock, jaundice, or acute renal failure

Empirical antibiotic therapy in septic abortion is started for the broadest microbial coverage. Piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem and clindamycin are given intravenously. Antibiotics can be changed once culture sensitivity reports are available.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man reported that he washes his hands 15-20 times a day, to the point of it taking a toll on his workplace performance. He says this is due to repetitive thoughts that his hands are contaminated with dirt. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The man is suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), as evidenced by the obsession (doubt that his hands are contaminated), followed by a compulsion (washing his hands way too many times). An obsession with contamination is a common symptom of adult OCD.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions. These recurrent obses­sions or compulsions cause severe distress to the patient. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. A compulsion is a conscious, standardized, recurrent behavior, eg: counting, and checking, and is done in order to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession.

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRIs or clomipramine
  • Behavioral therapy: Approaches include:
    • exposure and response prevention
    • desensitization
    • thought stopping
    • flooding
    • implosion therapy
    • aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioural and pharmacotherapy is most effective.

questions.text: What is the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.

During early puerperium, sloughing of the decidual tissue causes vaginal discharge which is known as lochia. Most women experience an increase in the amount of bleeding at 7-14 days secondary to the sloughing of the eschar on the placental site. But the average duration of lochial discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days.

The lochial discharge appears as follows:

Name Colour Timing after delivery Content
Lochia rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink After 3-4 days

WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms
Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat cells

The persistence of red lochia beyond one week might be an indicator of uterine subinvolution. The presence of an offensive odour, large pieces of tissue or blood clots in lochia, excessive or absence of lochia might be a sign of infection.

questions.text: A patient present in the ward when asked, "what is your name?" repeats the same sentence back to you. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Echolalia is a type of complex vocal tic, where there is the repetition of last-heard words of others.

Tics are semi-voluntary neuropsychiatric events characterized by brief rapid motor movements or vocalizations. These are typically performed in response to irresistible premonitory urges.

Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types.

Simple motor tics Complex motor tics

Composed of repetitive, rapid contractions of functionally similar muscle groups.

 More purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics.

Examples:

Eye-blinking

Neck-jerking

Shoulder-shrugging

Facial-grimacing

Head shaking

 Examples: 

Grooming behaviours

Smelling objects

Jumping

Touching behaviours

Echopraxia (imitation of observed behaviour)

Copropraxia (display of obscene gestures)
Simple vocal tics Complex vocal tics
It consists of sounds that do not form words. Repeating words or phrases out of context.
Examples:

Coughing

Throat-clearing

Grunting

Sniffing

Snorting

Barking

 Examples: 

Coprolalia (use of obscene words or phrases)

Palilalia (a person's repeating his or her words)

Echolalia (repetition of the last-heard words of others)

questions.text:
The normal placenta is _____

1. Discoid
2. Hemochorial
3. Deciduate
questions.solution:
The human placenta is of discoid, deciduate and hemochorial type. 
  • Placenta is discoid like in shape.
  • It is deciduate as it is shed at the time of parturition.
  • Hemochorial as majority of it is vessel derived.

questions.text: Which of the following is the next step in the management of an old patient who has undergone complete excision of glioblastoma?
questions.solution:
Standard treatment post-surgical resection of glioblastoma includes radiotherapy in older patients. Radiation alone is effective as a single-modality therapy in the elderly owing to the survival benefit of radiation. Moreover, the combined-modality therapy of Chemoradiation has increased the risk of Neurotoxicity.

It is used in combination with temozolomide chemotherapy in younger individuals. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. 

Glioblastoma is the most common adult primary intracranial neoplasm. It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (IDH) and Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis of the same. 

Clinically, patients usually present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure or focal neurologic deficits depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found infiltrating the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have greyish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

According to the WHO Classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

  • Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:
    • About 90% of cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age
    • Worst prognosis
  • Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:
    • About 10% of cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients
    • Poor prognosis
    • Glioblastoma, NOS (not otherwise specified), where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).

questions.text: A 75 year old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anaesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of severe uterine prolapse in elderly women. Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case.

This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

This procedure can be performed under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia. The vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, the raw areas are apposed in the midline with catgut sutures. This prevents the uterus from prolapsing.

This operation limits marital functions; hence, it should not be advised in women who wish to retain sexual function.

Other options

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (Option A) 
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation (Option B) 
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation (Option D)

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:


In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

The following image shows a voiding cystourethrogram in a patient with grade V VUR:

questions.text: A patient with unilateral breast cancer is started on tamoxifen. This will increase the risk of?

choices.text: Breast cancer in the opposite breast

questions.solution:
Tamoxifen increases the risk of endometrial cancer by 1-2%.

The benefit of tamoxifen in breast cancer outweighs the risk of endometrial cancer.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Koebner's phenomenon is not seen in herpes.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response: physical trauma, including friction, pressure, incision and laceration, skin grafting, bites, vaccination skin tests, burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV) and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. Other associated disorders include Darrier’s disease, pityriasis rubra pilaris, lichen nitidus, DLE, necrobiosis lipoidica, and Grzybowski syndrome.

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect ____
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who don’t have the disease or the true negatives.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease.

questions.text: The major contributor to demographic burden is __________.
questions.solution:
Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio, mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.

The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

Note : 

A decline in the dependency ratio especially the young age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor underlying the rapid economic development.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Other options:

Option A: Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Option B: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to
  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Small volume of food intake
  3. High osmotic load of food
  4. Increased release of insulin
  5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with features of late dumping syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. This occurs due to an increased release of insulin and hypoglycemia.

Dumping syndrome occurs due to rapid gastric emptying. It is commonly seen following gastric surgeries. It can be divided into

  • Early dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestions of foods with a high osmotic load. Increased osmotic load in the intestine leads to the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract. Patients will develop hypovolemia and hypotension.
  • Late dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestion of a large volume of meals and meals which are rich in carbohydrates. A large amount of glucose is absorbed from the intestine which leads to a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This in turns results in increased release of insulin which causes hypoglycemia. 

The mainstay in the management of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. The patient is advised to have small volume, regular meals that are rich in protein, fat, and low in carbohydrates. Somatostatin analogue like octreotide is used in the management of intractable syndromes.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium, for the past 2 months. Abdominal palpation reveals splenomegaly. His hemogram and peripheral smear results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hemogram:

Hb - 10 gm/dL

WBC count - 1,65,000/cu.mm (Leukocytosis)

Platelet count - 3 lakhs/mm3

Peripheral smear: 

Metamyelocytes - 15%

Promyeloblasts - 30%

Myeloblasts - 45%
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing a garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with a peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%)

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to emergency following bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks. She's in hemodynamic shock with a positive serum beta hCG. On examination, a mass is palpable in the lower abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is implying a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, as suggested by:

  • History of amenorrhea for 7 weeks: clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically appear six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.
  • Bleed per vaginum: amenorrhea of >4 weeks preceding the current vaginal bleeding suggests an ectopic gestation.
  • A positive urine/serum beta hCG test: suggestive of pregnancy.
  • Unstable vitals: suggestive of internal blood loss.

An unstable patient with this finding should undergo urgent surgical consultation and exploration i.e. laparotomy. It reduces haemorrhage and, also gives a better view of the operating field to the surgeon.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination, the left breast appears as shown in the image below. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with breast abscess has not responded to multiple attempts of aspirations. The next best step in this scenario is to perform incision and drainage.

The given scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The initial management of breast abscess includes aspiration of abscess along with supportive measures like a breast support garment, cold compression on the breast and analgesia to aid in symptomatic relief. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding. But her aspirations have been unsuccessful and thus incision and drainage have to be the next step in the management of this patient.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of the lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to a retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscesses.

It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just a superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of the breast or inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common deficiency observed after gastric bypass/bariatric surgery?
questions.solution: Iron deficiency is the most common deficiency observed following gastric bypass or bariatric surgery. Iron is absorbed in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, bypass procedures lead to or exacerbate an existing deficiency by impairing absorption. It is more common in the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS) procedures than in sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the emergency department with massive, sudden onset hematemesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with sudden onset haematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding. 

The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:

  • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen
  • Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
  • An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
  • Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
  • Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
  • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS

Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent for acne fulminans?
questions.solution:
Propionibacterium acnes is believed to be responsible for acne fulminans. 

Acne fulminans is a severe destructive form of acne. It is predominantly seen in white, adolescent males.

The exact etiopathogenesis of this disease is unknown. However, the presence of elevated testosterone levels and infection by Propionibacterium acnes has been implicated.

The patient clinically presents with sudden onset of multiple ulcerative and hemorrhagic nodules over the face, back, and trunk. In addition, the lesions may be accompanied by various signs and symptoms of systemic inflammation like fever and arthralgia.

The onset of these symptoms is commonly heralded by the presence of mild to moderate acne for 6 months to 2 years. Treatment failure to antimicrobial therapy is seen.

The diagnosis is clinical and the management entails:

  • Removal of crusts by soaking the crusts in an emollient oil.
  • Applying a potent steroidal/antimicrobial cream over the lesions for 2-3 weeks after the removal of crusts.
  • Oral prednisolone(0.5-1 mg/kg) therapy should be started and tapered over 2-3 months.

Systemic symptoms like fever and arthralgia are treated using oral salicylates or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all over the world is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding globally is senile endometrial atrophy, that is atrophy of the vaginal mucosa or endometrium.

Hypoestrogenism in a menopausal woman causes atrophy of the endometrium and vagina. In the uterus, the atrophic endometrial surfaces contain little or no fluid to prevent intracavitary friction. This results in microerosions of the surface epithelium and a subsequent chronic inflammatory reaction, which is prone to light bleeding or spotting.

Other Options :

  • Cervical cancer : Cervical cancer is the most common cause of post menopausal bleeding in India, and not over the world.
  • Endometrial cancer : Endometrial cancer is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in developed countries, and not over the world.
  • Hormone replacement therapy : Hormone replacement therapy is the second most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding all over the world.

Note : Endometrial cancer accounts for 10 % of cases of post-menopausal bleeding. Still, all postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma, since this potentially lethal disease.

The confusion kill : Remember, no cancer is as prevalent as the hypoestrogenism in a postmenopausal woman and this is why senile endometrial atrophy is the most common cause of bleeding in them, and not any cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following type of hypersensitivity reactions is seen in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction is seen in myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies directed against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies that react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

questions.text: Alcoholic liver disease is suspected in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting. Which among the following makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely?
questions.solution:
An AST: ALT <2 makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely. 

In alcoholic liver disease(ALD), usually the AST: ALT is > 2:1. This is due to:

  • Deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise.

In ALD,

Option B: Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver.

Option C: Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Option D: Serum total bilirubin can be normal or elevated with advanced disease.

questions.text: Identify the type of psoriasis in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The picture shows scattered drop-like papules and plaques suggestive of guttate psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is a distinct variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults. 

On examination, guttate psoriasis manifests as numerous, small scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as “drop-like” and typically manifest as round or slightly oval 2 to 10 mm papules. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs as shown below. 

 

The image below shows a typical lesion of psoriasis characterised by erythematous plaque covered with silvery scales, particularly over the extensor surfaces.

Other options:

Option B: Erythrodermic psoriasis is an uncommon type where almost the entire body is affected, and the patient is systemically ill. 

Option C: Pustular psoriasis is associated with the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.

Option D: Flexural/ inverse psoriasis has plaques affecting intertriginous folds, and scaling may be less prominent. It is shown in the image given below

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed at a railway station. As there was no pulse felt, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed ventricular fibrillation. Immediate defibrillation was performed. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths.

This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI given represents meningocele. 

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass, that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele-

questions.text: A 42-year old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, the supine abdominal x-ray shows air beneath the diaphragm along with Rigler's double-wall sign indicating pneumoperitoneum. The likely cause for this would be peptic ulcer perforation. Consumption of alcohol and chronic tobacco smoking are high-risk factors for developing peptic ulcers. Fever and tachycardia suggest peritonitis from the perforated ulcer. 

Gastric ulcers are more prone to perforate than bleed. Thus, these perforations lead to pneumoperitoneum which is an emergency and warrants immediate surgical intervention.

 Other options: 

A. Tension pneumothorax - presents with a rapid hemodynamic compromise with absent breath sounds. Pneumoperitoneum rarely is caused by pneumothorax, and downward displacement of air is more likely seen in retroperitoneal spaces.

C. Boerhaave syndrome or spontaneous esophageal rupture - occurs in alcoholics after binge drinking, due to forced vomiting from the closed glottis.  Pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema are seen here. 

D. Mallory Weis tear - longitudinal mucosal tear resulting in upper GI bleeding. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

questions.text: Gout can be precipitated by all of the following drugs except ______
questions.solution:
Gout is not precipitated by high-dose salicylates (>3g/day). 

Although high-dose salicylates inhibit both secretion and reabsorption of urate, the inhibition of reabsorption is more than the inhibition of secretion, and therefore the net effect is uricosuric.

On the other hand, low dose salicylates are associated with uric acid retention. They inhibit renal tubular secretion of uric acid resulting in hyperuricemia and may precipitate gout. 

Note: Aspirin is contraindicated in gout.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with the complaint of a palpable painless mass in the left breast. On examination, the mass was highly mobile, measured 3x3 cm, and was rubbery in consistency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fibroadenoma of breast. It presents as painless, palpable lump and is rubbery in consistency.

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade.

Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types:

  • Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition
  • With complex features - 
    • Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change
    • Classified as proliferative changes without atypia

Fibroadenomas are benign tumours, although neoplasia may develop in the epithelial elements within them. Cancer in a newly discovered fibroadenoma is exceedingly rare; 50% of neoplasias that involve fibroadenomas are LCIS, 35% are invasive carcinomas, and 15% are intraductal carcinoma.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Popcorn calcification is seen in mammography.

Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Giant fibroadenomas are >5 cm in size, common in adolescent girls, and require excision by submammary incision.

The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A woman who sustained third and fourth-degree burns on her back has been brought to you. What would be the order of sequence in her management?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in management is Resuscitation - debridement - allograft or autograft. 

Fluid resuscitation in burns:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is done in adults with second degree and third degree burns > 15% TBSA (Total body surface area) and in children with burns > 10% TBSA.

According to ATLS 10th edition, 2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns in adults is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA. 50% of the total fluid is given in the first 8 hours after the burns injury and the remaining 50% is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This can be calculated as:

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

For a patient presenting 8 hours after sustaining thermal burns, the total volume using resuscitation formula should be given in the next 16 hours i.e; 2 mL/kg × % TBSA in the next 16 hours while maintaining a target urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

In adults, urine output should be maintained between 30 and 50 cc/hr to minimize potential over-resuscitation.

In case of paediatric burns, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 3 mL/kg × % TBSA.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

This formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with a history of increased frequency of micturition. On cystoscopy, a pale ureteric orifice was seen. The patient's KUB X-ray is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and KUB X-ray point to the diagnosis of bladder tuberculosis. 

The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

A thimble bladder is a small contracted bladder due to fibrosis of the bladder walls. It is seen in bladder tuberculosis and is appreciated in a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). The X-ray KUB given above shows a thimble bladder.

questions.text: Preconceptional use of ______ leads to reduced incidence of neural tube defects.
questions.solution:
Pre-conceptional use of folic acid reduces the incidence of neural tube defects and folic acid is the commonly used active form of vitamin B9.

Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets daily to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Note that, non-pregnant, non-lactating Women of reproductive age (20–49 years) who are not actively planning a pregnancy in near term should receive 1 iron and folic acid tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid. 

 

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

A key intervention is to give IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of anemia, under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme.

Note: These values are specified for the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme (2018).

(6-59 months of age)

1 mL iron and folic acid syrup.

Each mL iron and folic acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid.

Bottle (50 mL) to have an "auto-dispenser" and information leaflet, as per MoHFW guidelines in the mono-carton

(5-9 years of age)

Weekly,

1 Iron and folic acid tablet.

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated, pink-colour.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,
