Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

questions.text: A 50 year old woman consults the doctor for the presence of a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. Despite anticoagulation therapy, she has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image represents necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to assess the degree of muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Train of four protocol is the best method to clinically assess neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade. It is done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

Tetanic stimulation (Option A): It consists of a series of extremely rapid electrical stimuli typically applied over 5 seconds. This method has only 70% sensitivity to detect residual paralysis and its specificity is only about 50%, and is painful. Hence, this test is of limited value for assessing residual neuromuscular blockade. 

Double-burst stimulation (Option B): Here two short bursts of 50 Hz tetanic stimuli is delivered, which are separated by 750 ms.

Electromyography (Option D) has been used to measure abdominal and thoracic motor function but is neither practical nor specific.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of chronic smoking presents with the complaint of dysphagia. Out of the following, which type of lung cancer is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In heavy smokers, the most common types are small-cell lung cancers and squamous cell carcinoma. 

Small cell carcinomas have the strongest association with smoking. The most common lung cancer in lifetime non-smokers, light smokers (<10 pack-year history), women, and younger adults (<60 years) is adenocarcinoma. Smoking is a major risk factor for developing lung cancer. Other risk factors that can contribute are industrial chemical exposure, air pollution, etc.

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

SCLC may be distinguished from NSCLC by the presence of neuroendocrine markers including CD56, neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), synaptophysin, and chromogranin.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes:

choices.text: Epidermis and variable parts of dermis

questions.solution:
Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes epidermis and variable parts of the dermis.

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft): include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: Which of the following CT findings is not an indication to perform angiography in a splenic trauma patient under conservative management?
questions.solution:
In a splenic trauma patient under conservative management, angiography is indicated if the CT shows a high-grade injury rather than a low-grade injury (subcapsular hematoma covering 40% surface area is a grade II injury).

In splenic trauma patients that are managed conservatively, angiography is indicated if there is the presence of the following CT findings:

  • Contrast extravasation
  • Presence of pseudoaneurysm
  • Significant hemoperitoneum
  • High-grade injury
  • Evidence of vascular injury

Management of Splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

  • They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively.
  • Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals and serial CECT.
  • If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis.
  • If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable or if there is a contrast blush, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of Grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of Grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries: These patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

questions.text: An 18 year old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This female with a 6 months chronic history of symptoms along with the presence of a palpable abdominopelvic mass suggests genital tuberculosis. 

Genital tuberculosis commonly affects women in the reproductive age group. It presents with menstrual irregularities such as amenorrhoea, menorrhagia, dysmenorrhoea, pelvic pain. Non specific symptoms like fever and weight loss are also present. It affects fallopian tube causing infertility, tubo-ovarian masses, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx. Pelvic and abdominal peritoneum is often involved with multiple tubercles, ascites and abdominal masses.

Other options:

Option A: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia, dyspareunia, pelvic pain, infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss.

Option B: Ovarian malignancy can also present with symptoms like abdominal fullness, bloating, nausea, abdominal distention, early satiety, fatigue, change in bowel movements, urinary symptoms, back pain, dyspareunia, weight loss, palpable pelvic mass or ascites . But this patient's young age and a chronic course of 6 month is unlikely to be a malignancy.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents as amenorrhoea followed by an acute symptoms of vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain in a reproductive age women. It does not have a long course of 6 months and other symptoms seen in this girl.

questions.text: A 25-year-old P1L1 woman is planning for her second child. She has been recently diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following is the antithyroid drug to be used in early gestation?
questions.solution:
When available, propylthiouracil should be used in early gestation because of the association of rare cases of aplasia cutis congenita and other defects, such as choanal atresia with carbimazole and methimazole.

Propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. Following which it is replaced with methimazole (or carbimazole) at a ratio of 15–20 mg of propylthiouracil to 1 mg of methimazole.

The lowest effective antithyroid drug dose to be used throughout gestation to maintain the maternal serum-free T4 level in the upper limit of the non-pregnant normal reference range.

questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing a CABG procedure.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The Left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: A patient sustained a crush injury on their right arm as depicted in the given image. He was brought to the hospital and on examination, his arm is pulseless, swollen and dark red. What would be the best way to manage this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a crush syndrome with compartment syndrome. If compartment syndrome is confirmed (by measuring intra-compartmental pressure), then fasciotomy is performed.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Management of crush syndrome involves aggressive management of the open wound and radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis. Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules. Renal hemofiltration is recommended if there is oliguria or renal failure. If compartment syndrome is confirmed (by measuring intra-compartmental pressure), then fasciotomy is performed.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure (ΔP). If the differential pressure (ΔP) is less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals), immediate compartment decompression is indicated.

Treatment:

  • Prompt decompression of the affected compartment is done.
  • All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat.
  • Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg
  • Fasciotomy wounds are left open and after 2 days if there is necrosis debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy it can be sutured without tension or skin grafting can be done.

questions.text: 74 year old gentleman presents to the OPD with history of significant unintentional weight loss, loss of appetite and iron deficiency anemia. A chest x-ray was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario indicates the patient may be suffering from colon carcinoma. The X-ray depicts cannon ball appearance classical of lung metastasis.
Pulmonary metastasis typically appears as peripheral, rounded nodules of variable size, scattered throughout both lungs. The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastases in adults include:

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Colorectal carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labour and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, BP 150/90 mm Hg and has a tense abdomen on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Premature separation of a normally implanted placenta is placental abruption. 

Hypertension and smoking are important etiological factors in abruption. Hypertension leads to vasospasm of the placental blood vessels, which causes uteroplacental insufficiency. 

The hemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This leads to a compromise of circulation to fetus leading to fetal distress. The bleeding may escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.

The common etiological factors for abruptio placentae include:

  • Hypertension
  • Preterm prematurely ruptured membranes
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Cocaine abuse
  • Trauma
  • Uterine fibroids
  • Isolated single umbilical artery
  • Short umbilical cord
  • Prior abruption
  • Subclinical hypothyroidism

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

Other options:

  • Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Hypertension is not a predisposing factor. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.
  • In preterm labor, fetal movements are not compromised.
  • Hydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall on their outstretched hand. The image given below shows the cast used to manage the patient's injury. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass holding position is known as the scaphoid cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion as if the glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends to just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray doesn't show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture. 

Related Pearl: Plaster casts and their uses:

  Name of cast   Usage

Minerva cast

Risser’s cast

Turn-buckle cast

 Scoliosis 

Shoulder spica

U-slab/hanging cast

Hip spica

 Fracture of the femur

Patellar tendon bearing cast

 Fracture of tibia

Colle’s cast (hand shaking)

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start LMWH. 

Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, and fetal embryopathy if used in the first trimester. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin.

Period of gestation Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

 LMWH or UFH
13 to 36 weeks Warfarin
36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery LMWH or UFH
6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin, UFH- Unfractionated heparin 

Heparin should be discontinued just before delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then iv protamine sulfate can be given. Warfarin or heparin anticoagulation can be restarted after 6 hours of vaginal delivery, usually without any problem.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

questions.text: A young boy with fatigue is found to have a haemoglobin of <9 g/dl. Peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are diagnostic of sickle cell anemia. The next best step is blood transfusion. 

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure and acute chest syndrome

questions.text: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee. Plain radiograph shows the following finding. What is the best treatment for the given condition?

choices.text: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a displaced patellar fracture. The best treatment for the given condition is tension band wiring with K- wires.

Other treatment options which are available for patellar fracture are:

  • Undisplaced patellar fractures with minimal joint incongruity and intact extensor retinaculum can be treated by cylinder cast.
  • Displaced patellar fractures are usually treated by tension band wiring.
  • Severely comminuted fractures where the reduction of the fragments is difficult are treated by patellectomy.

Related Pearl: Tension band wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

questions.text: Which of the following demographic indicators is used to compare the life expectancy of two different countries?
questions.solution:
The demographic indicator used to compare the life expectancy of two different countries is Human Development Index(HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development. The components include:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita.

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

 Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI).

questions.text: Which of the following incisions would be used during an open appendicectomy procedure?
questions.solution:
McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision), marked 3 in the image, is popularly used for open appendicectomy. It is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favoured in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is bronchiectasis. The CT scan shows the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis where the internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

The clinical scenario observed in bronchiectasis is: 

  • Repeated chest infections 
  • Presence of large amounts of yellow sputum 
  • Non-smoker 

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of one or more bronchi, which occurs due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defences, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with

  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Radiological findings - Chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. 

CT findings include:

  • Signet ring sign 
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Note: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss are the commonly associated symptoms. CT findings of pulmonary tuberculosis are Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease[COPD], is inflammation-induced destruction of lung parenchyma resulting from cigarette smoke or other pollutants. Patients typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Option C: Bronchial asthma is an airway hyperresponsiveness disease characterized by reversible airway narrowing and obstruction by mucus plugging. Patients typically present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. CT findings in bronchial asthma are bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

questions.text: A young man presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, breathlessness, and blurring of vision while trekking on a mountain at an altitude of 5000 meters. He is unable to climb any further. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Altered mental status is a clinical finding indicative of the development of high-altitude cerebral edema. 

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and water through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

  • Mechanical factors: loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).
  • Increased chemical mediators of permeability: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) (option C), nitric oxide, and cytokines (option A).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with:

  • Headache
  • Altered mental status (progressive decline of mental function and consciousness)
  • Papilledema leading to a blurring of vision
  • Breathlessness (due to hypoxia)
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude, and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension. Glucocorticoids are administered as well.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: GCS of a patient who had a road-traffic accident is 10. Using the GCS scoring system, the head injury of this patient is classified as:
questions.solution:
Using the Glasgow Coma Scale score(GCS) , the head injury of this patient with a GCS 10 is classified as moderate.

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. The maximum GCS score is 15 (E4 V5 M6).

Based on the GCS score, the head injury sustained can be classified as follows:

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • ≤8 represent severe injury 

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
The findings in the chest X-ray suggest asbestosis.

The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. 

Workers in the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Other options:

Option A: Berylliosis (chronic beryllium disease) commonly occurs in workers exposed to beryllium, typically in industries like electronics or aerospace, not in cement. On imaging, it usually presents with diffuse interstitial lung disease, nodules, or enlarged hilar lymph nodes.

Option B: Tuberculosis (TB) often appears as upper lobe infiltrates, cavitation, or miliary patterns on imaging.

Option D: Silicosis, often seen in industries such as mining or quarrying, presents with nodular opacities, especially in the upper lobes, and may have eggshell calcifications in the hilar lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with complaints of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.solution:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.

The procedure involves the resection of septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the outcomes.

Jones metroplasty, Strassmann metroplasty, Tompkins metroplasty involve approaching the uterus transabdominally which causes uterine scarring and are hence not preferred.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Identify the marked sign that is seen during 8 weeks of pregnancy.
questions.solution:
The sign seen in the 8th week of pregnancy giving a dusky bluish discolouration of the anterior vaginal wall is known as Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

Some other signs seen in pregnancy are given in the image below:

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta previa.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: Blood spill in the operation theatre is cleaned with _____.
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills; it is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people of which 15 had the disease. 22  people tested positive for the disease among which 14 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In this scenario:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14 (TP)

8 (FP)

22

Test -

1 (FN)

91 (TN)

92

Total

15

99

114

[TP- True positive, TN- True Negative, FP- False positive, FN- Flase Negative]

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100. Thus, sensitivity is 93.3%.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke is
questions.solution: Window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke is 4.5 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a condition to be fulfilled by a male undergoing sterilization?
questions.solution:
Eligibility for Male sterilization:

  • Clients should be at least 22 years old.
  • Clients should be below the age of 60 years.
  • Clients should be ever-married.
  • The couple should have at least one child, whose age is above one year unless the sterilization is medically indicated.
  • Clients or their spouses must not have undergone sterilization in the past (not applicable in the cases of failure of previous sterilization).
  • Clients must be in a sound state of mind, so as to understand the full implications of sterilization.
  • Mentally ill clients must be certified by a psychiatrist, and a statement should be given by the legal guardian/spouse regarding the soundness of the client's state of mind.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf, initially after walking a distance of 400m later 200m over the last 6 months. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of peripheral arterial disease which has worsened over time. This patient who prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain now has rest pain.

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) presents as intermittent claudication (crampy pain in the muscles). As the disease progresses, claudication distance decreases, and pain occurs even at rest called ischemic rest pain. Rest pain is due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. The pain is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot due to the loss of the gravitational effects on perfusion pressure. It may be lessened by hanging the foot down. 

Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on the raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

The initial investigation done is an ABI. Further investigation is done with Doppler imaging, duplex scan, and digital subtraction angiography. Rest pain is seen when ABI becomes <0.5. 

Other options:

Option A: Sciatica - The patient complains of pain radiating down the back of the thigh and calf. Sciatica can either be because of inflammation of the sciatic nerve or because of compression of one of the roots constituting the sciatic nerve

Option B:  Neurogenic claudication occurs with changes in the position of the back such as bending forward and straightening. It takes more time to be relieved by rest (more than 5 minutes). In spinal stenosis, there is an abnormal narrowing of the central canal, the lateral recesses, or the intervertebral foramina to the point where the neural elements are compromised.

Option C: Patients with venous claudication have some form of venous diseases like varicose veins, edema and skin changes due to chronic venous diseases like pigmentation, eczema or ulcers.

 

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: All are true about the initial management  of acute bleeding from esophageal varices except _______

choices.text: pRBC is used to maintain Hb betwwen 7-9g/dL
IV octreotide is used to acheive hemostasis
Upper endoscopy is only performed after 12 hours

questions.solution:
Upper endoscopy is performed within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation in variceal bleeding. 

The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:

  • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen
  • Blood transfusion with pRBC or platelets to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
  • An attempt at hemostasis with IV octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
  • Upper endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
  • Endoscopic variceal ligation of sclerotherapy
  • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS

Nonselective beta-blockers are used only in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.

questions.text: The best way to plot trends in the incidence of diarrheal disease in a given area is by?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot trends in the incidence of a disease in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A man brings his father who became unconscious while working in a field in the hot sun at 42 degrees Celsius in May. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte values were normal. The physician found that the body temperature was 106 F. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient is highly suggestive of heatstroke. The symptom least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.

Heatstroke occurs due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. The person fails to lose heat by cutaneous circulation and sweating. It is likely to develop when the body temperature rises to a range of 105°F to 108°F. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, and physical activity

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

It is a medical emergency that leads to homeostatic imbalance. The symptoms include dizziness, abdominal distress, vomiting, delirium, and eventually leading to loss of consciousness. On examination, the skin is dry, hot, and flushed, with a complete absence of sweating (anhidrosis). Other signs seen in heat stroke are tachycardia, Kussmaul-type rapid deep breathing (tachypnea), hypotension, cardiac failure, dizziness, muscle cramping, confusion, and seizures. Heatstroke can cause damage to multiple organ systems, including the brain, kidneys, and liver, which can lead to life-threatening complications. It is essential to initiate rapid cooling and supportive care measures to prevent permanent injury or death. The cooling methods used to treat heatstroke include:

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9o Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 102oF.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

Related Pearl: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text: The correct preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
The correct preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safest hysterectomy surgery to minimise the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table?
questions.solution:
Vaginal hysterectomy is the safest surgical approach to minimize the risk of ureteric injury on the OT table.

This is because the vaginal approach allows surgeons to follow natural anatomical planes and typically requires less dissection and manipulation of the uterus.

In a retrospective review of study involving 3114 hysterectomies, the following rates of ureteric injury were noted :

Procedure Incidence of Ureteric injury
Abdominal hysterectomy (5/940) 0.53%
Vaginal hysterectomy (1/304) 0.33%
Robotic hysterectomy (7/1088) 0.64%
Laparoscopic hysterectomy (4/782) 0.51%

Procedures that are associated with highest risk for ureteric injury are (but they are not the most common cause of ureteric injuries):

  • Surgery for malignancy
  • Advanced pelvic reconstructive surgery
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Urinary tract injury occurs almost exclusively in major gynecologic surgery that involves surgical dissection in proximity to the ureters or bladder. Vaginal route for hysterectomy tends to have lower rates of ureteric injuries than open or laparoscopic routes.

Patients with ureteric injuries have a complicated post-operative period. They can present with the following features:

  • Fever
  • Flank pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Prolonged paralytic ileus - bowel sounds are absent
  • High drain outputs, in case abdominal drains are placed.

CT urogram and retrograde pyelography are the investigations of choice. They reveal urinary extravasation from the ureter. Ureteric injuries are prevented by careful division of tissue planes during pelvic or genitourinary surgeries. The condition is managed by prompt surgical repair by ureteroureterostomy or percutaneous ureterostomy.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth chart shows his BMI between 85th and 95th percentile. Which of the following categories would you place him in?
questions.solution:
The boy is said to be overweight as his BMI-for-age percentile falls between 85th and 95th percentile.

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema

Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD

questions.text: A known case of asthmatic bronchitis reported to the hospital with breathlessness, palpitations and oxygen saturation of 88%. The hospital does not have a ventilator. All of the following can be given to the patient, except?

choices.text: High flow oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with asthmatic bronchitis and a saturation of 88% is suggestive of acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). High flow oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir is contraindicated as it can cause dryness, crusting epistaxis, and damages the lung hence not used. 

In patients with COPD, a saturation of 88-92% should be maintained to avoid acidosis. 

Oxygen is initially administered with a venturi mask at 24% until PaCO2 levels are rectified. 

COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction.  It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Patients present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. Diagnosis is based on pulmonary function tests and the severity is graded according to the global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease (GOLD) criteria. 

Pharmacotherapy of COPD includes:

  • Muscarinic antagonists: ipratropium, tiotropium
  • Beta-agonists: salbutamol, salmeterol
  • Theophylline
  • Inhaled corticosteroids

Acute exacerbations are managed with inhaled beta-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, oxygen, mechanical ventilation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation, and antibiotics.

Smoking cessation and lung volume reduction surgery in some emphysematous patients are the other interventions associated with reduced mortality.

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55 year old with simple hyperplasia of endometrium with atypia?
questions.solution:
Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in the above case.

Best treatment of atypical hyperplasia in a post-menopausal woman is hysterectomy.

Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Non-atypical hyperplasia:

  • Pre-menopausal women: Progesterone therapy
  • Post menopausal women:
    • Simple hyperplasia without atypia: Follow up without therapy
    • Complex hyperplasia without atypia: Progesterone therapy

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

  • Pre-menopausal women: High-dose progesterone therapy
  • Post-menopausal women: Hysterectomy

questions.text: A mother complains that her child is reluctant when it comes to taking feeds appropriately. Her 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median is having moderate stunting.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also called as wasting as a result of a recent food deficit or an acute illness such as diarrhea.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight for age, or underweight indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children. Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age) is given in the pearl below.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature being less than 95°F.

In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia. As the temperature drops below 90°F, there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.

With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves, or hypothermic waves, are best seen in the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to about 60°F.

Other options:

  • Hyperkalemia: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.
  • Hypokalemia: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.
  • Hypocalcemia: Prolonged QTc interval, occasional T wave inversion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease.

Water-washed diseases are those which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply. Some examples of water-washed diseases include shigellosis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, scabies, typhus, polio, etc.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the swelling and the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing an eccentric expansile lesion with a soap bubble appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor (GCT).

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment :

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting. 
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

Other options:

Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

 

Osteosarcoma:

It is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

 

Osteochondroma:

Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. The common sites of involvement are the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination neck rigidity is present and there is hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was done and CSF findings are as shown below. What is your diagnosis?

Opening pressure - Increased 

Colour- Cloudy white

WBCs - 7000/µl; neutrophil predominant 

Sugar- 15 mg/dl

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2 

Protein - 70 mg/dl

Latex agglutination - positive

Limulus lysate test - negative
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and CSF examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. 

The classic clinical triad of fever, headache, and neck rigidity is suggestive of meningitis. Other common complaints are nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Nuchal rigidity (“stiff neck”) is the pathognomonic sign of meningitis. Hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck is called Brudzinsky's sign.

Following are the classical CSF examination features suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

Opening pressure  >180 mmH2O
WBC

10/μL to 10,000/μL; neutrophils predominate
RBC Absent in non-traumatic tap
Glucose

<2.2 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL)
CSF/serum glucose <0.4
Protein

>0.45 g/L (>45 mg/dL)
Latex agglutination

May be positive in 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Escherichia coli, group B streptococci
Limulus lysate Positive in gram-negative meningitis
Culture Positive in >80%

 

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Chloride Low Very low Normal
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

Note:

In partially treated bacterial meningitis, CSF can be clear, with normal glucose levels and lymphocyte predominance. Culture is usually sterile, and antigens can be detected by an agglutination test.

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is _____________
questions.solution:
CuT 380 A has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard): It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. Hence the Copper T-380A has been able to achieve superior contraception while maintaining a similar side-effect profile

The Copper T-380A has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the life span of the Copper T-380A.

The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

IUCD Life span
Cu T 380A 10 years
CuT 200 3 years
Multi loaded Cu 250  3 years
LNG IUS /Mirena

5 years
Progestasert 1 year
Nova-T 5 years

questions.text: What is used to diagnose the condition given in the below image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk, pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. A Wood's lamp is used to diagnose the condition. Lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence when examined under the lamp.

Tinea versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous). The site most commonly affected is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen (seborrheic areas).

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 DM is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose - 520 mg/dl and urine tests positive for ketone bodies. A diagnosis of DKA is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the management of hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin preferably regular insulin.

Lente insulin and NPH insulin are intermediate-acting insulin and therefore, not used.

Management of DKA

  • IV fluids – 0.9 % saline
  • IV short-acting insulin (regular insulin) bolus
  • IV short-acting insulin infusion
  • Treatment of precipitating events – Infections by antibiotics
  • K+ replacement – In the later stages, since insulin therapy causes hypokalemia

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS (transvaginal USG) and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation for abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy: The investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • A Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.
