questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the OPD with a deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is your line of management?
questions.solution:
The first line of management of the given image, congenital vertical talus deformity (CTEV), is manipulation and cast by Ponseti's method.

Congenital Vertical Talus deformity/Rocker-Bottom foot: It is a rare deformity usually affecting both feet where the medial arch is not only flat, it is also the most prominent part of the sole, producing the appearance of a rocker-bottom foot. The talus points almost vertically towards the sole.

Management:

  • The first line management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:
  •         C- Cavus 
  •         A- Adduction
  •         V- Varus
  •         E- Equinus
  •         Ponseti's method is the currently used method for conservative management of CTEV.
  • When passive correction is not possible. ‘Reverse Ponseti’ technique (where the foot is stretched into plantar-flexion and inversion while counter pressure is applied to the medial aspect of the head of the talus), 4-5 plaster casts are usually required until the plantar-flexed talus is in line. This is followed by stabilization of the talonavicular joint with an open approach.

Following is the image of congenital vertical talus which has pre-operative, intraoperative and postoperative radiological images.

Ponseti's method is currently used for the conservative management of congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), while Kite's method was previously followed. Conservative management is preferred for CTEV

  Ponseti's method (Preferred)

Kite's method (Not used now)
Preferably start treatment within  <2 weeks of age 1 month of age
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus adduction - inversion -equinus
Fulcrum  Head of talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast
Duration of treatment 6-8 weeks 6-9 months

 Below is the image of CTEV/Clubfoot.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Five days after a common bile duct injury, there is a leak, and the patient  presents with fever and abdominal pain . What will be the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
In the case of a common bile duct injury with a leak and patient presenting with signs of localized peritonitis, the next step of management is ultrasound-guided aspiration, followed by ERCP and stenting.

Common bile duct injury: The most common cause of bile duct injury is laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 Management

  • If detected on table with
    • Duct injury less than 3 mm or those draining less than single segment of the liver: Ligation
    • Lateral injury—Duct injury more than 4 mm or those draining multiple hepatic segments: Repair using T-tube.
    • Transection with minimal loss of duct length: Repair using T-tube is used; in case of extensive loss of duct length, billiary enteric anastomosis is performed.
    • Cystic duct leaks can be treated by the percutaneous drainage of intra-abdominal collection and endoscopic biliary drainage. 
  • Post-operative detection of leak: Major biliary leakage is usually seen 2 to 10 days after cholecystectomy. Affected patients typically present with fever, abdominal pain, and/or bilious ascites. Jaundice is usually mild. Leukocytosis and abnormal liver function tests, particularly elevations in the serum levels of alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase, are common.  
  • Radiological workup: Upon presentation, transabdominal ultrasonography is initially performed to define the extent of possible bile leak. 
  • For definitive leaks, ultrasound-guided aspiration is performed; alternatively, the collection is drained and a transhepatic biliary drain is placed. After 6–8 weeks, the definitive repair is ascertained. 
  • Ultrasonography confirmation and aspiration of the leak is followed by endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and stenting.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for treatment of falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy_______
questions.solution:
Treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy:

  • 1st trimester: Quinine
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT-AL in North Eastern states and ACT-SP in other states.

Treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy:

  • DOC: Chloroquine
  • Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made and she was posted for laparoscopy surgery. During the procedure,  dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis and the next step in the management of this patient is cystectomy and adhesiolysis. 

After the surgery the patient is advised to start infertility treatment too.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • Gestrinone is an anti-estrogenic, anti-progestational, and mildly anabolic drug that reduces sex-hormone-binding globulin to release free testosterone. It also decreases the LH surge. It causes regression of lesions and amenorrhea. It is a 19-nortestosterone derivative similar to danazol, but with fewer side effects. 
  • Combined oral contraceptives are used for symptom control and alleviate disease. These also cause menstrual cycle regulation and delay pregnancy. 
  • Oral progestogens exert an anti-estrogenic effect and cause decidualization and endometrial atrophy. This causes disease regression. It doesn't prevent ovulation, thus is suitable for women who are trying to conceive. 
  • Mirena IUCDs reduce dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. It is a single-sitting treatment with minimal side effects. 
  • Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are anti-estrogens given for disease regression. 
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs like mefenamic acid and naproxen relieve dysmenorrhea.

Therapeutic procedures:

  • Aspiration of Peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac removes PGE2, relieves dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and improves fertility 
  • Destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser or CO2 vaporization can be attempted. 
  • Larger lesions and chocolate cysts can be excised. 
  • Cystectomy can be done for pelvic pain but can reduce fertility potential. 
  • Laparoscopic breaking of adhesions relieves dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. It also restores tubal patency and improves ovulation. Pre-sacral neurectomy can be done simultaneously.. 
  • Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: The most common anomaly in a child presenting with recurrent urinary tract infections is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of recurrent urinary tract infection in children is vesicoureteric reflux.

VUR occurs when the submucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent. VUR usually is congenital and often familial

Vesicoureteric reflux is more common in females.
